body: @jlahoda Would you update this one, or close it if this is no longer relevant.
Sorry, hadn't gotten time to look at this yet. I see this patch is gradle-specific--does the same problem occur for Maven/Ant?
Well, I'm unsure of Maven, as of Ant they do a heavy by-character output processing so probably not.
@sdedic Any further comments before I ask for this to get merged?
@jtulach not completely ready yet; just cluster.config=basic seems to be fixed, release is to be done soon (hopefully). Will enable then.
No, please go ahead. Thanks for the fix!

True, this approach allows NetBeans to eliminate reflection when accessing modern Java APIs. Let's prove that by modifying `applemenu` - a module that desperately wants to use JDK9 API. The current version does that with a bunch of reflection and some adhoc library not even published on Maven. 

Commit 31a7eb9 shows how to introduce new `applemenu.jdk9` with `javac.target=9` and use the JDK9 API without any hacks.
Thank you for the review, I will update it asap

Did you try resizing the window and making sure that the new Swing layout behaves properly?

I looked through add*Listener calls, found no obvious memory leaks (no listening on global objects, just components within the same panel).

Seems harmless!
I've tried to resize. it behaves reasonably good.
-0 I share @matthiasblaesing misgivings pretty much - how many uncertain forks of javac are we willing to keep relying on?!  Not a block though - I'll leave you to convince Matthias to remove his.

I had some private exchange regarding this subject. I said that I won't Veto this. And I stand by these words. That does not mean, that I agree with merging this. I think it is an error, but I won't stand in the way.

What concerns me is, that NetBeans _again_ becomes a experiment field and that that will affect the whole code base. Once this is merged and used, our way back is cut or at least removing it will be so painful, that is equivalent to a lock-in. So it comes down how much we trust the entity behind frgaal.

At this point I have no reason to trust into it. I'm not aware of any track record of the authors in the javac compiler area, my concerns were not addressed and I did not find any discussion about it in the OpenJDK mailinglists. I see a single vendor, which is in stark contrast to the OpenJDK javac, which is backed by multiple entities. If one of these entities decides to abandon OpenJDK, other vendors will step up, with frgaal it is EOL. It would help to know about other projects, that are already using it and what will happen with frgaal in the next years.
Duplicated?
Ok, lets close for now (I think it is worth to do, just don't have time).

Nice! Better info when building / using fluent APIs definitely a plus.

Is the setting for this same as method parameters? Would prefer separate.
Completely agree. Thanks for doing this.
Question: Should we backport this one to 12.0 as a patch so it would be usable running on JDK 15+?

Thanks for the input @matthiasblaesing. 

> The javadoc file for 6.14.3 is empty - this looks broken.

The javadoc is empty from the maven repository, I used the javadoc version 6.13.1 since there are no API changes.
> testng 6.14.3 has two transitive dependencies: bsh (2.0b6) + jcommander (1.72) at least jcommander was part of the dist package used before - don't we need it?

You were right about needing jcommander, I added it and everything run fine (no need for bsh).
>Was a project (preferably both ant and maven) tested, whether the results are still correctly reported?

I tested a maven and ant project, they both compile and run the tests successfully, cheked that the javadoc works to. 
>Does the unittest from java.j2seproject still run? (direct dependency on the module)

How can I check this? I compared the build logs and there are no errors and have the same number of warnings .
After restarting  a some test task in Travis a few times, I suspect that this PR fails some tests in ergonomics. @sdedic could you look at that?

> After restarting a some test task in Travis a few times, I suspect that this PR fails some tests in ergonomics. @sdedic could you look at that?

Sorry, seems to be based on slightly older master (hmtl.ojet was removed in the meantime). Rebased, squashed.

> Question: Should we backport this one to 12.0 as a patch so it would be usable running on JDK 15+?

No, I don't think it's necessary. Master declares a hard dependency `nashorn.execution` -> `libs.graaljs`, so it is usable on both JDK < 15 and >= 15.

Some more discussion is needed: the failure is caused by making `libs.graaljs` showing in AU. The containing feature (webcommon) is then enabled, which fails the test.

BUT as I played around with pristine builds of `cluster.config=java`, it seems the patch could be very shorter:
- if there's NO `webcommon` cluster in the distribution, then there's no JS support, so `nashorn.execution` does not activate (no text/javascript MIME recognizer). So no Run or Debug actions and Javascript are plaintext files anyway
- if there's `webcommon` cluster, then `nashorn.execution' loads the `libs.graaljs` and everything is fine
PLUS
- it seems little ridiculous to support hypothetical config that contains pieces of clusters (i.e. javascript, but not graaljs). If some distribution does such packaging, let it solve the problems as well.

That would leave only `OpenIDE-Module-Recommends:` in `nashorn.execution` with no fancy AutoUpdate UI suggestions.

@JaroslavTulach @entlicher -- agreed ? If so, I'll reduce this patch.

Had some time to evaluate the wider consequences. I fear, that this could mean the end of visualvm in Ubuntu/Debian. Debian requires the packages to be boostrapable from source. If this goes according to plan, the platform will not be buildable with a normal javac (openjdk javac and ecj), so debian will need to package frgaal. I don't see this happen, as frgaal pulls in a full JDK and questions will be raised what is so special about netbeans, that we don't use one of the widely used compilers.
I agree wit that simplification, it looks sufficient to me.
OK, edited again, simplified as outlined / agreed on.
Agree with the concerns here. (I read over the PR a few days ago but saw that the obvious problems had already been pointed out, so I didn't comment then...)

-0.9 as of me. If we move forward I'd rather really set the source and target to Java 11, even if we need to maintain a branch/fork of platform with Java 1.8 support. Even willing to provide some time to release the platform binary compiled with 1.8. Though that would be a different discussion. Though I have no burning urge to go that route at all. I'd be happy if we would just lift the source level to 1.8 first. Probably throwing out some 1.5 related code (profiler, laf hacks). So baby steps...

How was this merged? I don't remember seeing this asfgit merge something before...

Maybe we should back this out now, as there doesn't appear to be a majorly strong push from the author or anyone else to keep it in compared to the concerns being raised about it.

@mcdonnell-john asfgit is the bot the asf uses to synchronize gitbox (the apache side of the git hosting) and github. If you see asfgit somewhere, it indicates the changeset came in from the apache side (for example because a committer pushed a commit to gitbox).
Thanks @matthiasblaesing I saw this earlier and thought it looked odd.
@matthiasblaesing as an agreement with the rollback, would you be kind to merge this. We might wait for the CI to pass, that's your call.

For the records the PR was prepared by issuing:
```
git revert -m 2 814184b
```
@lkishalmi while I agree with the revert, I'm not happy that I'm asked to merge this. I have too much involvement, so it would be better if another person would do it.

Could there be something else to revert here?

>  I'd rather really set the source and target to Java 11

Just for the record: -1 against dropping JDK8. Thank you.

Well, this is not the "dropping JDK 8" discussion. I think that one would come eventually a few years later. On short term I would be just happy if we can lift the source level on all our modules to Java 8, then remove some ancient support, like Java 5 profiler, some LAF hacks, etc.

This is about whether we would allow to depend on another 3rd party compiler in the exchange for some syntax candy.

@mcdonnell-john I was able to reproduce your problem. It happes if the build JDK and the target JDK are not the same. I had this in my ".nbbuild.properties":

```
#permit.jdk9.builds=true
nbjdk.home=/home/matthias/bin/jdk-8
```

This will lead to ant finding the desktop classes, while in the compile run they are not present. I switched that back to my normal setting:

```
permit.jdk9.builds=true
#nbjdk.home=/home/matthias/bin/jdk-8
```

And can now compile the platform cluster cleanly. I checked against 12.1 branch and the problem can be reproduced/fixed there identically. Please see if that helps.
Thanks @matthiasblaesing I'll check when I get home.

> This is about ...  some syntax candy.

No, it is not! True, original motivation (in 938b7d2 and 6066163) might be the syntax candy. I agree that is the useless part. However 31a7eb9 shows it is not candy at all. It is about ability to **compile against future Java APIs on JDK8**. With such ability...

> Well, this is not the "dropping JDK 8" discussion.

...we would never need to have "dropping JDK 8" discussion again. Think about it, before [rolling back](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2369).

This gift comes with a hefty price: Dependence on a single entity and an uncertain future. 

The discussion about the baseline JDK will always come up, because the classpath changes. Consider the new http client libraries, the upcoming additions of project panama (improved JNI), project loom (green threading) and so on. At the price of more complexity in netbeans you can again hide them behind compatibility shims, but that won't scale long.

The build failure in the unittest can be explained by https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/eba3ee243620628c58e7c69710d8b1b9642fc02c and https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/eff3db303db7ca8cb599df834d7e47f99bcf3bd4.

@lkishalmi could you please rebase this PR onto latest merges to master?

I was thinking adding ant index-layer-paths  (list of all the registred elements Actions , Editors).

Please accept an apology for not spotting the problem sooner: #2371
There is talk about reverting #2337, as that commit is at least controversial.

> The module with javac.target=11is only enabled when running on JDK11+, otherwise it is disabled.

So what happens when the module is run on JDK8? Yeah it won't work and thus I can compile against JDK9+ API, but I won't be able to rely on it. My point is, that we still need to decide which is the baseline JDK we expect. That won't magically go away - independently of the javac used.
No worries @dukescript

So I thought about this some more and looked at the wider ecosystem. My suggestion is this:

- let #2369 go through, reestablishing the working state of the netbeans repository
- drop #2371 as it is followup for #2337 which is being reverted by #2369
- discuss the suggestion on the dev@ mailinglist as it has enough consequences to warrent a wider audience
- see what is the outcome of that discussion and if it goes through reprepare a PR with the then agreed changeset

What I noticed is, that there is in fact a java compiler out there, that has the property to support target < source. It is the eclipse compiler. Given that they base a whole IDE on top of it, that survived a few years, I would say, that it is battle proven. Maybe at some point the OpenJDK javac will reach the same state and the changeset that is used to create frgaal might be pushed upstream and thus available to the wider ecosystem.

+1 to @matthiasblaesing suggestion, and for what it's worth a retrospective change from -0 to -1 on this PR (was not expecting the veto to be dropped after "private exchange" or the debate to be curtailed).
"Rebased" on the current master.

During further implementation, it turned out that the `MimeRegistration` change may be insufficient: there are folders where the registration order is not important. 
And even folders like `UpToDateStatusProvider`, where **multiple** service types are registered; such folders should not define ordering at all (it does not make sense to specify linear order between two different service kinds, right ?)

So I am tempted to extend the API with `MimeLocation.Ordered(true/false)` that would determine whether the Processor will auto-generate positions. By default all FS-based Lookups are order-sensitive, so it may make sense to explicitly declare the opposite.

@jtulach ?
@jlahoda  vs @jlahoda-jackpot ?  Interesting. However, what is the state of this PR? Has @jlahoda fixed the issues mentioned by @jlahoda-jackpot ?

+1 on @matthiasblaesing  from my side as well. I'm going to merge #2369. That will make #2371 obsolete. @dukescript or @JaroslavTulach shall start a discussion thread on the dev@ list. Let's come to an agreement there.
If we end up supporting the intentions of #2337, then @dukescript can file a new PR which combines #2337 with #2371 

We are not in a hurry. Let's sit down and talk.
Well just read the change in #2371 it is independent from all of this, and can be supported to be merged.

> > The module with javac.target=11is only enabled when running on JDK11+, otherwise it is disabled.
> 
> So what happens when the module is run on JDK8? 

You cannot run such module on JDK8, that's the point. It contains 
```
OpenIDE-Module-Java-Dependencies: Java > 11
```
in its manifest. As such the [runtime container knows](https://bits.netbeans.org/12.0/javadoc/org-openide-modules/org/openide/modules/doc-files/api.html#std-sec) such module shall not be enabled on JDK8, JDK9, JDK10.
@pepness can we get this one updated? Probably to 20.2.0?
Thanks for the patch @matthiasblaesing, I will integrate and re-test everything.
Of course, will update to latest and re-test.
Patch was integrated and tested, everything was ok. Thanks @matthiasblaesing.
This is now working in 12.1, but it seems the javadoc of the Record is not included in the autocompletion, like in the case for a Class, for example.
@pepness @daemontus There is another PR proposed in #2372, I think it would be good to coordinate the efforts
Just checked the PR and it has everything. Closing this PR in favor of [PR-2372](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2372)
Probably need to be rebased on the current master as webcommon tests are failing, also please check the failing GraalVM tests!

Sure, rebase coming soon :) Looking into the GraalVM stuff now - not sure what's happening there yet. Seems like GraalJS is fine, but anything that is using R/Python fails with `OutOfMemory` exception... I'll investigate more tomorrow.
@pepness thank you - could you please squash the changes into a single commit as the final change? As the checks now all come back clean, I would merge then.
This is reviewed, unittests come back green, lets get this in. Thank you for your work.
From my pov it looks promising :)
Do not forget about the licenseinfo.xml and add the apache license into the svg header (if that's possible)

We might consider a separate place for all the editable SVG files (maybe a resource folder in nbbuild?) and stripping out the unnecessary metadata in the shipped icons using eg. Inkscape's save optimized?  Mind you, if we have to have the license header in each SVG anyway, might not be worth it.

I don't think we should be doing these one-by-one. It will not end up looking good, and reviewing will take much longer than if we do 50-60 of these in batch at a time. For these particularly simple icons (a single square and a single circle), making the style consistent with other icons, and ensuring alignment to the pixel grid etc., is 90% of the work.

We need to do a full batch of icons from https://people.csail.mit.edu/ebakke/misc/netbeans-icons/prioritized.html , and ensure they are following some agreed-upon style guide (e.g. as proposed in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2617 ). Then we need to go in and make sure the vertices in the icons are aligned to pixel boundaries and so on.

(As an example: In these particular two SVG icons, the style is inconsistent with existing icons because the borders are too hard. The proposed style guide in NETBEANS-2617 prescribes 33% transparency for the border, on top of the fill color. The fill color of the "Stop Macro Recording" is also too dark--the shade of the old bitmap icon was better.)

So let's hold off integrating individual icons until we have a large batch done.
I would like to be able to just look at the icons. For example, an issue associated with this PR which had png files attached.

@eirikbakke however the svg creation happens initially, at some point in time new icons will be needed and then it will be the same situation as volunteers doing work now. I don't see us holding back new features, just because a blessed icon is not ready or until a full new batch is done.
Test
Tests are green, commits are squashed - Thank you.

> I don't see us holding back new features, just because a blessed icon is not ready or until a full new batch is done.

The feature here is, "make NetBeans look better". When it comes to icons, having a consistent scheme is an essential part of "looking good". So adding one or two icons only, which will now look different next to the existing ones in the toolbar, actually makes NetBeans look worse. Thus the -1.

To review, we also need to see screenshots before and after, at 100% and 200% DPI scaling. Often you'll see issues at this point, that were not evident when you were just looking at the icons in the drawing software. This means recompiling, which takes a while... longer than the time it took to draw two icons.

Unrelated: I also recommend keeping the icons in a single file in the drawing software (in different "artboards" or whatever is the equivalent in Inkscape), so they can be viewed side-by-side while designing them. This also facilitates cut-and-paste of shapes between icons.
@arusinha please merge if this is good to go. @singh-akhilesh is not a committer, so can't merge himself.
Also, these two icons have already been drawn... see the attachments to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-2617 . Some coordination is needed to avoid duplicating work.

@eirikbakke how do you suggest how it should work in the future? I don't have Adobe software, don't own a system that could run it and won't pay the money for the software. Am I not allowed to contribute GUI code anymore? Consider a new feature where 4-5 icons are needed, that are derivates of existing ones. I would have taken the SVGs, modified them and committed them with the new feature. Your approach basicly cuts me off from this way and adds a high reliance on proprietary software and a small (not yet exiting) number of people.

@matthiasblaesing For the scenario you describe, I think it would be fine to use Inkscape. It can open SVGs created by other software, and you can then use that to copy shapes. This is, of course, hypothetical until we actually have a large number of existing icons converted...
Inkscape can open Illustrator files, by the way--Illustrator files are technically just PDFs.

Hey @lkishalmi , I will clean up the profiling support for Java 1.5 in another pull request.. Thanks for the approval.
Hey  @matthiasblaesing , can I get a blessing from you on this.. I know you might not be a fan of this, given the previous comments, but could you still agree to move forward on it.
Thanks for getting it done Akhilesh , approved.
If I edit via Inkscape will it be savable on ai to keep metadata for so people using illustrator can modify or is it a one way edition ?

@BradWalker not sure whether you need my blessing :-) - I'm just attached to old architectures, because I was in the situation where a Java 1.4 VM was used in production as an embedded VM, currently a 1.5 VM standalone in production, so removing support without reason is always strange for me.

So I rephrase: If it helps, from my POV 32 bit solaris sparc can be considered obsolete and removed (Oracle as the main vendor of the platform already decided java support is not worth it anymore for the platform).

Well about the support of profiling 1.5 JVM. I think even NetBeans 8.5 is perfectly fine for that task. We are less sure about 12.0, hence I'd doubt anyone have tried that, but theoretically possible. One of the gray areas we have is the profiler support. The build does not really rebuild the source code with each release, just downloads some dusty zips and populate it's content. If we would like to move forward from this state, I think it's not bad to leave the rusty parts behind.
Also the state of the profiler worries me a little. Right now a modern JVM often crashes in a few seconds when attaching the profiler (at least on Ubuntu). It might be just some minor binary incompatibility or something else. So it would be at least good to have the profiler binaries rebuilt with each release.
Though I'm going to open a discussion on that on the dev mailing list.
@jherkel could you update this PR with the requested format change?
Hmmm isn't the upgrade happens from 4.3.25 -> 4.3.29?

Thank you - change looks sane, unittests come back clean, author information looks good.

@SiddheshRane I assume, that you agree that the changeset is donated to the ASF, if that is not the case, please say so, the merge will then be reverted.
Seems file to me. Merging.
@ebarboni Not sure, but I wouldn't count on the PDF import/export process being lossless. I'd also guess the SVG itself works better as a common file format.

Hey @matthiasblaesing , I agree with your comments about removing old h/w support. As a Sun person, it really, really bothers me to remove the old support because: 1 - the support will be gone forever, 2 - we loose historical information when this happens, and 3 - it's just one more door closed that reminds me of the past.. 8-)
Lastly, @matthiasblaesing since Laszlo approved it.. Can you merge the pull request? Please.. 8-)
